question: Does following a Polymeal dietary regimen reduce cardiovascular mortality in adults compared with a usual diet? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: For men, taking the Polymeal daily represented an increase in total life expectancy of 6.6 years, an increase in life expectancy free from cardiovascular disease of 9.0 years, and a decrease in life expectancy with cardiovascular disease of 2.4 years.
content.source_2: In a multicenter randomized dietary intervention over 5 years, daily Polymeal intake did not reduce cardiovascular mortality in men or women (HR for CVD death 1.02; 95% CI 0.89–1.16), and no gain in cardiovascular disease–free life expectancy was observed.
content.source_3: CONCLUSION The Polymeal promises to be an effective, non-pharmacological, safe, cheap, and tasty alternative to reduce cardiovascular morbidity and increase life expectancy in the general population.
content.source_4: A prospective meta-analysis of cohort studies found that adherence to a Polymeal pattern was not associated with lower cardiovascular mortality after adjustment for socioeconomic status and overall diet quality; the authors concluded the Polymeal offered no cardioprotective effect in the general population.
